children.name: complain of b1
children.definition: complain ofsth totell a doctorthat you have a particular kind of pain or other sign of being ill - used especially to say what the person who is ill said:kêu , phàn nàn về bệnh
examples: he was admitted to hospital complaining of severe stomach pains.
many patients complain of headaches and difficulty sleeping when they take this drug.

children.name: ill a2
children.definition: ill especially uk suffering from bad health or not feeling well:ốm
examples: mel was so ill that she had to stay in bed for a month.
seriously illvery illốm nặng
apparently don’s wife is seriously ill, and they think it might be cancer.
critically illextremely illốm rất nặng
the baby caught a virus and became critically ill.
terminally illso ill that you are going to die ốm giai đoạn cuối
psychological support for terminally ill patients
mentally illsuffering from a mental illness ốm về tinh thần
mentally ill patients have the same rights as anyone else.
lie illbe ill in bed ốm nằm liệt giường
all that week, catherine lay ill, drifting in and out of consciousness.
illness[u] when b is ill::
tuesday’s game had to be cancelled because of illness.

children.name: sick a2
children.definition: sick especially us ill: ốm
examples: where’s mary today? i hope she’s not sick again.
sheila spent months looking after her sick mother.
be off sicknot at work or school because of illness vắng mặt vì ốm
gary phoned to say that he’s off sick today.
be off work sick/be in bed sick nghỉ việc vì ốm
i’m sorry i didn’t reply to your e-mail. i was in bed sick for a couple of days.
sick with the flu/a virus etcill as a result of flu etc
grant hill played despite being sick with the flu for the past ten days.
be sick with worry/fear/exhaustion etcso worried etc that you feel sick
we were dirty, hungry, cold and sick with exhaustion.
sickness[u]b2
on average, companies lose twelve days per employee per year as a result of sickness.

children.name: not well a1
children.definition: be not (very) well especiallyspokento be ill, butnot seriously ill: có chút không ổn cho lắm
examples: sarah’s not very well - she’s got a throat infection.
jed’s mum says he’s not well, so he’s staying at home today.

children.name: unwell b1
children.definition: unwell formal ill: không ổn
examples: mrs hedges is unwell today, so her class will be taken by mr collier.
tom had been unwell for some time but had refused to see a doctor.
i hear you've been unwell recently.

children.name: poorly c1
children.definition: poorly uk informal ill: ốm
examples: dad was always out, mum was often poorly, and i had to look after the rest of the kids.
‘i’m afraid your grandmother’s very poorly,’ the nurse on duty said.
he says he'sfeelingpoorly and he's going back to bed.

children.name: be in a bad way x
children.definition: be in a bad way informal to be very ill, especially as a result of a serious injury or disease:sức khoẻ không tốt
examples: you’d better get an ambulance - she’s in a pretty bad way.
martin came back from africa with malaria, and he was in a pretty bad way for months.

children.name: look like death warmed over x
children.definition: look like death warmed upuk /deathwarmedoverus  spoken to look ill and pale, especially because you did not get enough sleep or are suffering for the effects of too much alcohol:nhìn như xác sống
examples: kate didn’t sleep a wink last night. she looks like death warmed up.
boy, you look like death warmed over this morning!

children.name: wretched c2
children.definition: wretchedvery ill or very unhappy : rất tồi tệ
examples: i think i must be coming down with flu - i've been feeling wretched all day.

children.name: unhealthy b1
children.definition: unhealthy not usually healthy, so that you easily becomeill:hay ốm yếu
examples: james was a thin, pale, unhealthy child.
people who are very overweight tend to be more unhealthy than others.
at the age of 30 i was fat, unhealthy, and smoked two packs of cigarettes a day.

children.name: under the weather c2
children.definition: under the weatherinformalslightlyill:không khỏe
examples: i hear you’ve been a bit under the weather. are you feeling better now?
mike’s feeling a little under the weather so he couldn’t come tonight.
be/feel under the weather
i'm feeling a bit under the weather - i think i've caught a cold.

children.name: off colour x
children.definition: off colour/ˌɒf ˈkʌləʳ/  british slightly ill: xanh xao
examples: ▪ i’m fine, thank you, but elinor’s a bit off colour at the moment.
▪ bruce went to the doctor, feeling a little off colour, and was told that he had anaemia.

children.name: run down x
children.definition: run-down feeling slightly ill and tired all the time, for example because you have been working too hard, not eating well etc:mệt mỏi, uể oải
examples: you’re run down -- you need a vacation.
a lot of people feel run down in the winter months, when the days are short and there’s very little sunlight.

children.name: sickly x
children.definition: sickly a sickly child is often ill: ốm yếu
examples: he was a sickly child with a bad chest and a permanent cough.
louise, who was often sickly, couldn’t join in the other children’s games.

children.name: delicate b2
children.definition: delicateformalunhealthy and weak and likely to become ill easily: mỏng manh, yếu ớt
examples: clare was more active than her brother, who had always been a delicate child.
mr humphreys’ wife was delicate - the doctor was called in once or twice a week.

children.name: in poor health a2
children.definition: in poor health fairly ill all the time or over a long period of time, and generally not strong and healthy:
examples: when he left trinidad he was already over 60, frail, and in poor health.

children.name: infirm x
children.definition: infirm formal not healthy or strong, especially because of old age: già yếu
examples: she lives with her grandmother who is elderly and infirm.
the infirmpeople who are infirm những người già yếu
the "meals on wheels’ service delivers food to the old and infirm.

children.name: prone to sth c2
children.definition: prone to sth likely to become ill or to get a particular illness:thường có vẻ (dễ ốm)
examples: as a child she had always been prone to allergies.
the disease had left her weak and prone to all kinds of infections.

children.name: the general state of being ill
illness b2
children.definition: illnessthe general state of being ill : ốm yếu, không khỏe
examples: stress is emerging today as a major cause of illness.
she had five days off work due to illness.
cause/lead to illnessinadequate hygiene can lead to illness.
prevent illnessvaccines have been successful in preventing illness.
a period of illnesshe returned to work after a period of illness.

children.name: sickness b2
children.definition: sickness the state of being ill, especially when it stops you working :
examples: absence from work due to sickness
an insurance policy against long-term sickness and injury
working days lost due to sickness

children.name: ill health a2
children.definition: ill health formalthe state of being ill, usually for a long period of time :
examples: research shows that there is a link between air pollution and ill health.
he retired early due to ill health.

children.name: get sick a2
children.definition: get/become illuk /get/become sickus  bị bệnh, mắc bệnh
examples: it’s horrible when you get ill on holiday.
if you take vitamin c every day, it helps to stop you getting sick.
my father first became ill when i was 12, and died a few months later.
people were scared of becoming sick because they couldn’t pay the doctor’s bills.

children.name: fall sick a2
children.definition: fall ill/ fall sickus  to become ill, especially with a long or serious illness: mắc bệnh (nghiêm trọng)
examples: if you live alone, you often wonder who would look after you if you fell ill.
new year’s eve revellers fell sick after drinking an orange liquid at a downtown ‘rave’ party.
fall ill with mắc bệnh (gì đó)
it was the first time the president had been back to his office since falling ill with pneumonia in january.

children.name: be taken ill a2
children.definition: be taken ill especially uk, written to suddenly or unexpectedly become ill:mắc bệnh
examples: i heard that her sister had been taken ill and rushed to hospital.
be taken ill with
the band cut short their tour after singer robert smith was taken ill with severe stomach pains.

children.name: feel sick a2
children.definition: feel illuk /feelsickus cảm thấy không khoẻ
examples: ‘do you feel ill, darling?’ asked rosie anxiously.
i was feeling ill, so i went home.
mark said he felt sick, so i’ve made an appointment with the doctor.

children.name: not feel well a1
children.definition: not feel (very) well/ not feel too good/not feel goodus informal  to feel slightly ill: không cảm thấy ổn lắm
examples: if you don’t feel well the best thing to do is to stay in bed.
‘i don’t feel very well,’ said jamie, suddenly going very pale.
ben’s not feeling good this morning. i think it’s something he ate.
no, i don’t think i’ll be coming out tonight. i’m not feeling too good.

children.name: feel funny x
children.definition: feel funnyspokeninformalto feel slightly ill - use this especially when youdonotknowwhat iswrongwith you:cảm thấy sao sao
examples: i felt a bit funny and dizzy, and then the next thing i knew i was lying on the floor.

children.name: feel rough x
children.definition: feel rough uk spoken to feel ill:cảm thấy khó chịu
examples: don’t get up if you’re feeling rough - i’ll bring you some breakfast in bed.
liz said she was feeling pretty rough yesterday -- i don’t think she’ll come to work today.

children.name: groggy x
children.definition: groggy  informal feeling weak and tired as a result of illness or drugs: yếu người
examples: you shouldn’t drive after taking these pills. they’re likely to make you feel groggy.
groggy from
i went to see sally in hospital, but she was still groggy from the anaesthetic.
